title: The return of the intuitive designer in the age of AI
text:
The return of the intuitive designer in the age of AI

Stay relevant by honing your intuition, not yourÂ process

You likely know, or at the very least know of, a designer who just gets it. Iâ€™m talking about the designer who solves complex problems with elegant, user-centred, buildable solutions without breaking a sweat. Or maybe that designer who turns everything they touch into something genuinely beautiful. Or even the one who gets up on a stage and says what weâ€™re all thinking more clearly and eloquently than we can. Maybe all three. Love or irrationally hate them, there they are, making the things that you struggle with daily look easy. You look skyward and wonder, â€œwhat is it they have that IÂ donâ€™t?â€

The answer is intuition. They inherently understand what you donâ€™t, and itâ€™s the thing that separates good from great in every field. Paul McCartney just â€œgetsâ€ music. Einstein just â€œgotâ€ Physics. Chumbawamba just â€œgetsâ€ knocked down (and they get upÂ again).

But what do we really mean when we say intuition when it comes to design, and why is it resurfacing so vehemently as AI comes into our practice, guns a-blazinâ€™? And importantly, if youâ€™re not feeling particularly intuitive today, how do you fix that? Can you even? The answer is everyoneâ€™s favourite â€œyes,Â butâ€¦â€.

Intuition andÂ Design

If you unpack the concept of intuition, what is it really? For psychologist Daniel Kahneman*, â€œintuition is thinking that you know without knowing why you do.â€ People who intuit correct solutions easily have trouble explaining their process in reaching them.Â (Zulz)

Cognitively, intuition is explained by unconscious processes, and might also be called â€œexpertiseâ€. The brain is very good at learning implicitly, and can compare stored memories, patterns, and even emotions with a current scenario without â€œthinkingâ€. Your brain is even capable of activating what are called mental schemas, complex â€œchunksâ€ of information, which is how I suddenly still know how to drive whenever I (rarely) find myself behind the wheel of a car. (Cockcroft etÂ al.)

This figures into design as a practice more than other disciplines, because design trades in what are called â€œwicked problemsâ€; those that are ill-defined, and lack a single â€œcorrectâ€ solution. Design thinking pioneer Nigel Cross, writing in his landmark Designerly ways of knowing, separates design as a discipline, by the fact that it is solution, and not problem-focussed. (Cross 223). ForÂ Cross:

â€œWhat designers know about their own problem solving processes remains largely tacit knowledgeâ€Šâ€”â€Šie they know it in the same way that a skilled person â€˜knowsâ€™ how to perform that skill. They find it difficult to externalize their knowledge, and hence design education is forced to rely so heavily on an apprenticeship system of learning.â€(224)

Design-god Paul Rand, himself possessing a triumphant sense of intuition, stressed its importance, as a sense beyond instructions that can be followed, writing;

â€œNo system of proportion, color, or space can possibly insure meaningful results. A system can be applied either intuitively or consciously, interestingly or boringly. There is always an element of choice, sometimes called good judgment, at other times good taste. Aside from practical considerations, in matters of form the typographer, for example, must rely on intuition.â€

Intuition in design comes in many forms. For some, itâ€™s finding harmonious visual balanceâ€“ a nearly automatic application of Gestalt principles. For others, itâ€™s an immediate jump to a solution that just works, or an immediate pivot from one that wonâ€™t. Maybe itâ€™s that you connect the dots on where things are going naturally, without doomscrolling Medium. If youâ€™re intuitive, you get to skip the steps. Within every superstar designer, youâ€™ll find a refined intuition in some form orÂ another.

(Note: Kahneman spends a large portion of Thinking Fast and Slow identifying breakdowns in intuition that we routinely make. So when I talk about intuition, itâ€™s really intuition that turns out to be right. â€œGood intuitionâ€. Lots of people trust their intuition and come to wrong answers, which is why itâ€™s important to be critical of any idea that comes too easily. Gut-check your gut-check.)

Designâ€™s Skill Cycle, AIâ€™sÂ Tornado

If youâ€™re a student of history, or at the very least old, you know that change, when it comes to technology and work, follows a cycle. To begin, a small number of skilled workers produce a product or service that meets a need (demand). As that need expands, skilled labour runs short (supply), which triggers a process called de-skilling, which is exactly what you think it is; taking the skill out of the process in order to meet demand. This involves breaking down the process into small parts that can be done by anyone with training (think of the assembly line). Once a process has become as de-skilled as it can be, technology steps in and automates the process (once the cost of automation sinks below the cost of labour). This is classical economic theory, youâ€™ll find it in both Adam Smith and KarlÂ Marx.

Design has been through this cycle more than once. The creation of movable type in the 1450s gave swathes of scribes the heave-ho, and launched the careers of typesetters, and printers. The need for more printed materials launched type foundries, and improved printing presses, de-skilling the printing process, and making it easier and cheaper to do. Eventually printing automated many of its processes, and the cycle beganÂ again.

By the time the personal computer started entering households in the 1980s, it brought with it desktop publishing, which wiped out the typesetting industry save for a small cottage industry. A new set of skilled designers emerged using those programs, the glut of materials produced expanded, and again automated.

Even product design (or UX, or whatever you call it) has been through this cycle before. Before UX software existed, designers used Photoshop (or maybe InDesign), slicing up assets, and redlining pdfs to hand to developers. As the demand for UX design has grown (thanks to the internet and an explosion of digital products), technical solutions have made it easier to do more withÂ less.

UX today is well inside its de-skilling phase. With sky-high demand over the last decade, Human Computer Interaction, a field once reserved for artsy computer scientists, has ballooned into the field we know today. To meet the needs, it was imperative to de-skill the job. That began with the expansion of design education, and the creation of the â€œdesign processâ€ in a formal way. UI kits, design systems, best practice resources, heuristics, playbooks, as well as the absolute dominance of easy-to-use Figma in the field has made it easier than ever for someone with minimal training to â€œtrust the processâ€ and expect that the outcome will be good. A conglomeration of a slim few tech companies that steer the look and feel of virtually all digital products means that they set â€œbest practicesâ€, and those are easy to copy. Even the separation of the production process into product, design, and engineering is itself a breakdown of a very complex system into more isolated parts. Not quite the assembly line, although sometimes it might feel thatÂ way.

But whatâ€™s the next step after de-skilling? Automation. Weâ€™re seeing it happen live, right now. When Jakob Nielsen posts about Gemini potentially producing better UI than humans, you might feel a bit like a blacksmith pounding a horseshoe while a car rolls by. AI brings with it an automation of the parts of the information economy (and just the economy at large) that have de-skilled. UX design as we know it is most certainly in that category.

(A side note about progress: Do we care if itâ€™s bad? No! As much as we like to grump about how things were better back when ______(insert thing here), fortune typically favours the cheap over the good. Hooray for Capitalism! Will AI-generated UI initially suck? Yes. Will that stop it from becoming the default? No, not if you believe that history rhymes. Early assembly line produced products were horribly bad, but here weÂ are.)

The re-rise of the intuitive designer

Donâ€™t call it a comeback. But letâ€™s look at the facts. AI can produce UI today. And tomorrow itâ€™ll be a little better at it. Generative AI uses both training and models of inference to produce results. And itâ€™s capable of producing multiple solutions at once, very quickly. Any principles or best practices or research that youâ€™re working from can be ingested. So if your design skillset is centred around your diligence in following a process, or your ability to operate design software, well, things donâ€™t look great forÂ you.

Claude designer Jenny Wen, speaking at last yearâ€™s HATCH conference, said the quiet thing loud. In her talk â€œDonâ€™t trust the process,â€ Wen observes that the good design work sheâ€™s seen happen is rarely a product of process, and instead born from intuition and play. The reality is that the pace of work has accelerated, and the â€œdiscoverâ€ phase of the design process is increasingly seen as extraneous, given that an automated solution can come quickly (to be clear I donâ€™t personally love that this is happening, but it IS happening).

https://medium.com/media/7631d3b179288f2cc8ef6cdffde5e9b5/href

Not that they were unsuccessful before, but here is where the intuitive designer proves themselves to be more relevant than ever, perhaps exclusively relevant. Intuition provides the things that AI canâ€™t do betterâ€“ it can bring novel solutions to the table, and make judgments about potential solutions without certainty. Design intuition can also interrogate the problem, and the requirements set to ensure that they truly align. Recall the quote (apocryphally) attributed to Henry Ford, that goes: â€œIf I had asked people what they wanted, they would have said faster horsesâ€. AI can think of faster horses, intuition can think of cars. This has prompted some thinkers to posit the move from a knowledge-economy, to an intuition economy.Â (Rudin)

If the future of design involves democratising skills through automation by wielding AI tools, Wen says it best: â€œIn a world where anyone can make anythingâ€“ what matters is your ability to choose and curate what you make.â€Â (Wen)

Letâ€™s get intuit(ive)

Just as following a recipe doesnâ€™t make you a great chef and learning dance steps doesnâ€™t make you a great choreographer, flawlessly executing every step of the design process doesnâ€™t make you a great designer. Bridging the gap requires using your intuition to elide processes, and to make correct decisions hundreds of times as youÂ design.

If youâ€™re feeling a little glum, and not particularly intuitive today, fear not. Intuition is like a muscle, and just about anyone is capable of buildingÂ it.

One way is simply, experience. Thatâ€™s not to say job experience, but it certainly helps. The more design you experience, the more youâ€™ll build mental schemas and memories around design. Look at design, lots and lots of design. Think about it. Think about why things look the way they do, why this solution has been chosen. If it resonates with you, think about why that is. Develop your sense of taste. Have anÂ opinion!

Understanding how something actually works might give you more perspective on the problems present, and the solutions available, and might allow you to make connections others canâ€™t see. The great artist Michelangelo spent a creepy amount of time watching dissections, and even performing some. He was able to apply that knowledge to painting and sculpting in ways that showed the true dynamism of the human figure. If youâ€™re a car designer, you should know how metal works. If youâ€™re a digital designer, you should understand code.

Of course, design is not all about the artefacts, itâ€™s about the people who use them. Itâ€™s not surprising that many a great designer, musician, artist, etc. turn out to be either charismatic or provocative. What resonates with people in the work is intuitive to the maker. You need to understand people. For UX designers, thereâ€™s a lot to know about how humans notice, perceive, understand, and generally think that should impact your decision making. Humans also exhibit biases, and while we canâ€™t avoid them, we can study and understand them. Ultimately, you can turn all of this information back on yourself, and understand how and why you might be drawing conclusions.

Finally, design. And collaborate with others who do. With each problem you solve, the more you have to draw on for the next one. Collaboration and play, and time spent with peers and mentors are amazing ways to broaden your horizons. These are the reasons artistic movements, â€œschoolsâ€ of thought and practice, musical scenes, and even elite sports dynasties succeed. Even a little healthy competition sparks the need to be creative and intuitive (consider menâ€™s tennisâ€™ â€œbig three,â€ who collectively spent 900 weeks at number 1, who all claim that competition pushed them to new heights). While no one can teach you actual intuition, you can learn it â€œfromâ€Â others.

Of course, none of your intuition matters if you ignore it. Itâ€™s time to listen to that perhaps quiet but still persistent voice in your head that tells you when youâ€™ve really nailed it. Trying to be more like a machine is a losing battle. Might I suggest leaning into the whole â€œbeing humanâ€Â thing.

title: Test smart: how to solve dilemmas as QA?
text:
Test smart: how to solve dilemmas as QA?

Once the QA Engineer enters the room, everyone expects that quality issues will be magically solved.

Throughout my career in software testing, Iâ€™ve noticed dilemmas that affect the overall teamâ€™s dynamics and product outcomes. Believe it or not, these are the patterns that are quite common for every development team I worked with. These very patterns easily block the teamâ€™s goal, e.g. to develop an amazing cutting-edge product that could help humanity... As a result, this amazing product exists only in the requirements or in the dreams of the product owner. The team builds something elseÂ instead.

Some teams praise visibility over value, forget about quality in hectic sprints and approach testing without a clear strategy. Sounds familiar? Welcome to the reality of a QAâ€™sÂ job.

Visibility overÂ value?

In many teams, louder members get praised, even though their impact might be equal to that of more silent members. To find the typical example, just observe an average stand-up meeting. The ones who talk more get all the attention.

In her article, software engineer Priyanka Jain tells the story of two colleagues assigned the same task. One posted updates, asked questions, and collaborated loudly. The other stayed silent and shipped clean code. Both delivered. Yet only one was praised as a â€œgreat teamÂ player.â€

In many work cultures, we mix visibility with value. If you talk often, people assume youâ€™re contributing. If youâ€™re quiet, they assume youâ€™re not. That is why extroverted personalities get promoted more often than introverted ones.

If you are the only QA person on board, you need to be visible and vocal. Otherwise, your contribution goes unnoticed, the major bugs get ignored, and nobody cares about the productâ€™s quality. Some may even wonder what you are doing there because you donâ€™t shipÂ code.

If you are an introvert by nature and you donâ€™t like to exhibit your opinion or updates on every corner, it may be a challenge for you. However, this is a reality of â€œfast-pacedâ€ environments: the more vocal and visible you are, the better it is for theÂ team.

Quality is the oracle, but is itÂ really?

Quality is meant to be the oracle for a product team; it is something that the product team should strive for and manage accordingly. Otherwise, are you sure your customers would tolerate all those bugs and inconsistencies they run into? No team wants to see their product abandoned by the users. Yet, is quality really anÂ oracle?

Once, I had a debate with a developer about a feature. He argued that he would definitely make a toggle button instead of a drop-down menu because â€œit looked more fancyâ€. I asked him to visualise both versions in the prototype tool so we could test each option. In the context of our specific use case, the dropdown menu still looked like an appropriate choice.

After a brief testing session that we had done together, the developer gave up and agreed. We saved time on the potential rework. (Back then, AI wasnâ€™t so powerful yet. Right now, I would use an AI-driven tool to visualise both cases for the development team. So, we could also save time on a debate.) Anyhow, everyone was happy, including the customers who got a polished version of the product promptly.

Here, the quality mindset is something that could be learned on the way. The role of a QA person is also to promote this mindset, so team members become aware of it. When realising the priority of quality, the development team will do more to prevent bugs in production. Afterall, quality is a teamÂ sport.

Do we need a testing strategy?

Before I joined a team, letâ€™s call it X, it had no testing workflow, and the team wasnâ€™t confident enough to go through the release cycle. There was a usual panic one day before the planned release. The team wasnâ€™t yet conscious about quality. The overall feeling was like: â€œTesting? We just donâ€™t have time for it. Arenâ€™t you QA? You should figure out something!â€

The whole situation reminded me of the logic of Hattifatteners from Tove Yanssonâ€™s book, who were always on the move and wanted to reach the horizon at any price. Here, the price wasÂ quality.

In a month, I brought the team to the point where we had a hard talk about the current product quality and what we can do to release better. The team established a QA workflow that consisted of multiple testing techniques at various levels of the product (End-to-End, API, Unit). Agile Testing Quadrants, a tool first introduced by Janet Gregory and Lisa Crispin, were our framework for selecting testing techniques that matched team Xâ€™s needs. The overall product quality improved a lotÂ then.

Before a team starts building a quality assurance system for a product, it is smart to brainstorm on how quality assurance should function. It is important to define how the quality will be measured: which testing techniques will be applied to the product, and how overall testing coverage will be achieved.

It is vital to discuss the current testing status and how the team could prevent defects (which tests to use and at which level). After brainstorming sessions, the QA flow can be outlined by the team. Consequently, there will be less chaos and more peace of mind once the team ships theÂ product.

If you are struggling with similar dilemmas, there is always a solution for each. In an agile team, get more vocal and communicate the issues clearly. If the team forgets about quality in the reality of speedy sprints, remind them about it and involve team members in testing sessions. And finally, if testing efforts look messy, talk to your team about the testing strategy and create it together. Afterall, arenâ€™t you the one who can figure it out?Â ğŸ™‚

You may check my LinkedIn page if you feel like connecting with me or are curious about my background. As a QA Engineer with over 7 years of commercial experience in the industry, Iâ€™m ready to communicate with teams looking for guidance and help in enhancing product quality and testing. At this very moment, Iâ€™m looking for a new role as a QA Analyst, QA Engineer or QAÂ Lead.

text:
The AI delegation matrix: what parts of your UI shouldnâ€™t exist?

A practical scoring model to decide when to Delegate, Assist, or stay Human-Led.

This essay was originally published on my Substack Syntax Stream, where I write about principles of humanâ€“AI interaction.

For years, application design followed a straightforward goal: reduce friction so users can complete their jobs faster. We mapped flows, removed steps, and optimized interactionsâ€Šâ€”â€Šassuming the user would remain the primaryÂ actor.

AI changes that assumption.

Today, we find ourselves in a dangerous â€œmessy middle.â€ We are building software that can act, decide, and synthesize, yet we are still designing it as if it were a simple tool. If we want to build products people actually love, we have to stop â€œsprinklingâ€ AI onto our workflows. We have to answer one fundamental question:

Who holds the steering wheel at this specific moment, and what is the logic that justifies it?

We need a systematic way to move beyond â€œassistance everywhere.â€ We need to know when to step back and let the machine take the wheel entirely, and when to protect the humanâ€™s role as the accountable driver.

This article provides a practical framework that turns the â€œwho does whatâ€ decision into a repeatable process.

The Three ControlÂ Modes

Every task maps to one of three modes. Each defines who acts, who decides, and what the interface mustÂ enforce.

1) Human-Led

The human retains full control. AIâ€™s role is to surface evidence, highlight tradeoffs, and structure the decisionâ€Šâ€”â€Šbut never to act. The human reads, weighs, chooses, and executes.

Design goal: Improve decision quality and accountability by giving the human clear evidence, tradeoffs, and structured rationale support.

When to use it: High-stakes decisions requiring subjective judgment, empathy, or ethical nuance, or where the process itself createsÂ value.

Common UXÂ patterns

  • Evidence packs (relevant facts, sources, prior cases, policies)
  • Tradeoff framing (pros/cons, risks, alternatives)
  • Structured decision templates (criteria + rationale capture)
  • â€œSecond opinionâ€ critique (counterarguments, failureÂ modes)
  • Clear accountability cues (what is suggestion vs decision)

2) Assist

AI does the heavy liftingâ€Šâ€”â€Šgenerating drafts, running calculations, scanning documentsâ€Šâ€”â€Šbut cannot commit consequential actions without explicit human approval. The human reviews, edits, and signsÂ off.

Design goal: Maximize speed and iteration while ensuring safe commitment through previews, diffs, and explicit human approval at keyÂ points.

When to use it: High-variability tasks with medium-to-high stakes where errors are costly or hard to detect, and accountability must remain with aÂ human

Common UXÂ patterns

  • Draft-first flows (generate â†’ edit â†’Â approve)
  • Plan-before-execute (â€œhereâ€™s what I willÂ doâ€)
  • Diff-based review (show changes, not just finalÂ output)
  • Provenance panels (inputs, sources, constraints used)
  • Uncertainty and â€œwhyâ€ explanations (when/why the system isÂ unsure)
  • Tight correction loops (edit a section, regenerate locally)
  • Clear commit controls (approve/apply with scope visibility)

3) Delegate

AI owns the task. It acts autonomously within defined boundaries. Humans donâ€™t approve individual actionsâ€Šâ€”â€Šthey set constraints upfront and review outcomes after theÂ fact.

Design goal: Run on autopilot with guardrailsâ€Šâ€”â€Šminimize user involvement while keeping traceability, monitoring, and rollback whenÂ needed.

When to use it: High-volume, low-stakes, predictable tasks with clear success criteria and easily detectable errorsâ€Šâ€”â€Šwhere human review adds friction without adding value (e.g., data entry, spam filtering, meeting scheduling).

Common UXÂ patterns

  • Global constraints (allowlists, budgets, scopes, timeÂ windows)
  • Activity logs / timelines (what happened, when, and under whichÂ policy)
  • Monitoring by exception (alerts only on anomalies)
  • Rollback/undo where feasible (or compensating actions)
  • Audit views (sampling, QA workflows, policy compliance)

The ScoringÂ Model

Knowing the three modes isnâ€™t enough. You need a systematic way to decide which mode fits which task. These variables determine whether a machine should act and whether it is worth the investment to make it doÂ so.

Dimension 1: Automation Suitability (S_SUIT)

This measures risk and controllability. High score = safer to automate.

  • Reversibility: Can the action be undone? High reversibility allows for deeper delegation.
  • Safety / Risk: What is the â€œblast radiusâ€ of a failure? Catastrophic risks require human-led guardrails.
  • Logic Type: Is the task governed by objective rules (deterministic) or subjective â€œvibesâ€ (probabilistic)?

Dimension 2: Automation ROIÂ (S_ROI)

This measures value and feasibility. High score = strong payoff for building automation.

  • Frequency: Is this a rare occurrence or a constant, high-volume workflow?
  • Data Readiness: Is the necessary information messy and unstructured, or accessible via a structured API?
  • AI Proficiency: Does the current modelâ€™s capability show experimental results or consistent mastery of theÂ task?

Mapping Scores to ControlÂ Modes

To move from raw scores to a functional product strategy, the framework uses a four-quadrant matrix to determine the optimal relationship between the user and the machine. By plotting Automation ROI on the X-axis against Automation Suitability on the Y-axis, you can categorize any workflow into one of four distinct strategic buckets.

  • Delegate (High ROI / High Suitability): The AI executes end-to-end within constraints while humans move to an auditor role. The goal is work removal through invisible execution and background guardrails.
  • Assist (High ROI / Low Suitability): High-leverage tasks that are too risky for full autonomy. The AI drafts in steps, requiring a â€œhuman handshakeâ€ via previews and explicit approval at criticalÂ commits.
  • Human-Led (Low ROI / Low Suitability): High-stakes or subjective tasks where human judgment is the primary value. The AI advises with evidence, but the human remains firmly at the steeringÂ wheel.
  • Defer (Low ROI / High Suitability): Safe to automate, but the effort outweighs the gain. Keep these manual or use lightweight helpers until task frequency or AI proficiency shifts theÂ ROI.

Hereâ€™s an example: interview scheduling coordination.
Itâ€™s frequent and time-consuming (high ROI), itâ€™s mostly rules-based, low stakes, and easy to undo (high suitability). When we score it, it lands in the top-right quadrantâ€Šâ€”â€ŠDelegateâ€Šâ€”â€Šwhich means the product should run it end-to-end within constraints, and only pull a human in for exceptions.

The Cheatsheet

After scoring dozens of workflows, clear patterns emerge in how tasksÂ cluster:

(Human-Led): Anything involving ethics, legal commitments, personnel decisions, strategic direction, or crisis response. These tasks require judgment that canâ€™t be delegatedâ€Šâ€”â€Šnot because AI isnâ€™t capable, but because accountability must remain withÂ humans.

(Assist): Content generation, insight detection, triage, and any task where AI can produce a strong first draft but the final call requires human review. Payment approvals and moderation decisions sit here tooâ€Šâ€”â€ŠAI flags and suggests, humansÂ commit.

(Delegate): Data operations dominate this range. ETL jobs, categorization, normalization, spam filtering, scheduling, notification routing. High volume, structured inputs, clear rules, easy rollback.

The scoring isnâ€™t meant to be preciseâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s meant to force the conversation. When your team debates whether â€œcontent moderationâ€ is a 4 or a 6, youâ€™re having the right discussion about what level of human oversight that task actuallyÂ needs.

Apply the framework in 6Â steps

  1. List core workflows (10â€“30).
    Use verb+object: â€œschedule interviews,â€ â€œapprove access,â€ â€œtriage tickets.â€
  2. Mark commit points.
    Where does it become real: send/publish/grant/pay/write/delete?
  3. Score each workflow on two scales (1â€“10).
    S_SUIT: reversibility + risk/blast radius + rules vs judgment
    S_ROI: frequency + data readiness + AI performance
  4. Plot on the matrix and assign a mode.
    Human-Led, Assist, Delegate, Defer
  5. Design by mode (use proven patterns).
  6. Gate autonomy with metrics.
    Track errors, reversals, exceptions, time saved, and review quality (avoid rubber-stamping).

The delegation matrix doesnâ€™t tell you where to â€œadd AI.â€ It tells you what form of control to designâ€Šâ€”â€Šautopilot, copilot, helper, orÂ advisor.

Every task requires a specific answer to the question: â€œWho holds the steering wheelÂ here?â€

title: Design careers in the Age of AI: specialize or generalize?
text:
Design careers in the Age of AI: specialize or generalize?

How LLMs are reopening this questionâ€Šâ€”â€Šand why it could turn into a professional identityÂ crisis.

Text written manually without AI. Images made with Midjourney.

Maybe this text will become outdated as quickly as all the changes weâ€™ve seen happening in our field over the last few years. But even if I run that risk, I feel I need to write a bit about a feeling Iâ€™ve seen spreading more and more among designers who work with digital products: the crisis of professional identity.

Itâ€™s no longer recent that Artificial Intelligence has been popularized with the rise of LLMs accessible to all audiences on a global scale. Even if it started with large models focused on text, in a short time we saw the exponential growth of countless tools that create a bit of everything.

When this started to become increasingly evident in our field, I began to notice that people started to understand again that a return to the generalist designer was happening in the digital product space. NN Group even published an article talking about the return of the UX Generalist as a possibleâ€Šâ€”â€Šand also desirableâ€Šâ€”â€Šrole due to AIâ€™s advance in delivering so many different parts of ourÂ process.

The Return of the UX Generalist

At first, I interpreted that as positiveâ€Šâ€”â€Ševen while aware of the ethical and social implications of AI (which wonâ€™t be the subject of this text). However, looking more closely at the current landscape, what Iâ€™ve been noticing isÂ that:

the return to generality, with the help of the LLM models available now, doesnâ€™t necessarily have a positive effect and can generate superficiality and a reduction in innovation in the longÂ run.

In this space, Iâ€™ll explain more about this feelingâ€Šâ€”â€Šespecially for those who have been feeling anxiety about how AI may affect their professional and personal identity in todayâ€™sÂ world.

This text is not against the use of AI: itâ€™s simply an article with reflections on this current moment of interaction between designers andÂ LLMs.

Hyper-specialization as aÂ pain

In my masterâ€™s, one of the authors who helped me most in thinking about the way I liked to work was Edgar Morin. He is a thinker who talks about how all modern knowledge (especially since the Renaissance revolution of scientific knowledge) has been guided by simplification through reductionist thinking. This reductionism pushes the individual from a broad basic education into higher education restricted to a single discipline, and then into progressively narrower specializations (until itâ€™s expected they dedicate themselves to a single topic for the rest of theirÂ life).

Iâ€™ve always been averse to this kind of training, and I felt firsthand the effects of not following the expected path. It was only after many years that I realized doing that was very positiveâ€Šâ€”â€Šespecially seeing, in practice, this disjunction that Edgar Morin discusses so much in relation to twentieth-century education.

In these almost three decades that have passed in the twenty-first century, itâ€™s possible to see that the field of digital product design specialized so much that it ended up opening internal fissures. I tend to see this as, at least, three major axes in which people specialize and navigate:

  1. a communicational axis, linked to branding, language, and art direction, where the artistic side of the interface matters aÂ lot;
  2. an empirical-scientific axis, linked to research, methods, data, validation, and decision-makingâ€Šâ€”â€Šsometimes captured by ROI and return discourse, but not reducible to that;Â and
  3. an exact and technical axis, tied to software engineering, where part of design remained close to front-end, components, systems, and implementation, as was already seen more strongly aroundÂ 2010.

Of course, this happened because of the size of the complexity of each major areaâ€Šâ€”â€Šwith only the digital product part relating to communication between humans and machines. But even if thereâ€™s a justification, what often happens is a production line between closed niches that donâ€™t talk much to eachÂ other.

Hyper-specialization leads to less communication, since each part understands only its own area and its own topic in depth, but canâ€™t comprehend the issue that lives nextÂ door.

And with that, information passes from area to area until it reaches the professionals at the end of the process: developers. I bet many of you have already witnessed this phenomenon, which creates noise around impediments or disagreements.

Thatâ€™s why Morin talks so much about an education of the future in which complexity is embracedâ€Šâ€”â€Šin teaching that doesnâ€™t funnel down but opens horizonsâ€Šâ€”â€Šwhile maintaining depth of study. However, even if the Complexity Paradigm exists in the educational field (and I believe in it and defend it whenever I can), itâ€™s important to be cautious!

The effects of having professionals who can embrace so many different areas have always been desired by many sectors of the market. Thatâ€™s why the idea (even if often imaginary) of the â€œunicorn designerâ€ has always been so promisingâ€Šâ€”â€Ša caricature name given to the imagination of a â€œdo-it-allâ€: someone who, alone, produces a super artistic and interactive interface with decisions grounded scientifically and empirically, and can still make the solution tangible in front-end.

The â€œbutâ€ in this always-desired idea is that it isnâ€™t humanly possible to make a single professional transmogrify into roles that demand such different cognitive trainingâ€Šâ€”â€Šespecially if you want a product that is truly good in eachÂ aspect.

But this collective imaginary never stopped existing, and it has now been reborn with the emergence and popularization of Artificial Intelligence. By relegating activities to the machineâ€Šâ€”â€Ševen without specialized knowledge in a given areaâ€Šâ€”â€Šit would be possible to stimulate the existence of this professional who navigates every corner and can deliver well in any activity.

Itâ€™s at this specific point that a promise is bornâ€Šâ€”â€Šbut also countless risks that are not yet fully predictable.

Generalization as aÂ risk

Iâ€™ve been reflecting a lot on this issue. And more and more, I feel the problem isnâ€™t the promise of the return of the generalist in itself: the problem is the way this may emerge within the scenario weÂ have.

Look: unlike a reformed education in which people donâ€™t isolate themselves into niches, what can happenÂ is:

a professional who keeps the same aptitudes as before, but starts delegating to the machine responsibilities they donâ€™t really know how toÂ develop.

As the NN/G article approaches this issue, the professional can get an AI boostâ€Šâ€”â€Šthat is, manage to produce outputs in areas they didnâ€™t master before. The output is produced, but the userâ€™s cognition may remain the same asÂ before.

Okay, but whatâ€™s the problem withÂ that?

The issue here is that weâ€™re operating primarily with Large Language Models, created specifically by companies that operate on a global level. These models learn human language (whether textual or imagistic) from enormous amounts of data to generate, through statistics and probability, responses that are coherent to us, humans. In more technical words, they function as token â€œpredictionâ€ machines: given an input text (prompt), the model estimates what the most likely next token will be and uses that to build the output. I know each AI will have a more specific functioning (with image and video models), but in general, they all operate with statistics from the training specific to the company that createdÂ them.

Thatâ€™s why AI today is not an intelligence in the human sense of the word: itâ€™s a super complex machine that can learn countless patterns across all areas for which data is digitally available. Thatâ€™s why it (at least not yet) doesnâ€™t have what some have been calling neuro-symbolic reasoning.

A didactic example given by Massimo Attoresi is about reasoning in medicine: if a patient shows up with a rare symptom that has no report in previous studies, medical knowledge can be mobilized by a human to understand how to unravel that symptom. An LLM canâ€™t do that: it can hallucinate and produce plausible answers or images, because its training prioritizes generating believable responses, even in the absence of sufficient knowledge to solve certain problems.

For most users, itâ€™s more frustrating to receive an â€œI donâ€™t know,â€ which is a questionable UX decision of these platforms. So when a designer who had a specialty starts producing any other specialty with LLMs, they will begin developing that only with the support of that machine that brings the probabilistic result most desired by the global average. And, even more importantly, that person will understand that their work is the outputÂ itself!

On the contrary, a professional identity is not defined only by what is delivered at the end, but by the cognitive and symbolic construction that allows one to cross complex processesâ€Šâ€”â€Šincluding those still unknown to the models or to humanityÂ itself.

Iâ€™ve said so much here, and I wanted to add a parenthesis: yes, itâ€™s possible to do a lot of design using LLMs todayâ€Šâ€”â€Šin all instances of our work, including those we wouldnâ€™t be able to do without AI due to training limitations. Now, itâ€™s necessary to understand that when we train an agent to make the machine operate like a specialist in some part of the UX/UI process, weâ€™re always generating probabilistic answers without a neuro-symbolic background to face new, unmapped situations.

And itâ€™s exactly at this point that the risk lives. Itâ€™s a risk of homogenizing solutions, writing styles, innovation processes, visualsâ€Šâ€”â€Šand even code, in the case of massive reliance on LLMs. Unless the support comes from the professional identityÂ path.

The professional path asÂ identity

Think with me through anÂ example:

We have a designer who works with digital products and who has always, since very young, fit into a more communicational axis.
She spent years going deep to create highly visual platforms with unique animations that create an impact that many brandsÂ want.
She also grew by feeding on aesthetic sensitivity, managing to blend branding with product design very well in digital platforms.
In other words, everything she does visually is guided by the feeling built throughout that professional trajectory. And that feeling is based on concepts and methods studied for years, which allow her to get through very different problems without impediment.

That person today may look at the current scenario and begin to feel anxiety and an identity crisis: â€œMaybe my work wonâ€™t be valued anymore in some time because of AI.â€ With that, she might start using different LLMs, trying to deliver in research areas (both qualitative and quantitative) and also to produce Design Systems, creating already-coded components.

What will probably happen in the long run if this person doesnâ€™t start studying those fields instead of only creating outputs with AI? We lose a talent in one area to create a generalist who produces a bit of everythingâ€Šâ€”â€Šbut only through the LLM. And because itâ€™s only with the help of that kind of tool, her deliveries will tend to fit the globally expected statistical average.

Now, what happens if that same person starts using AI to deepen her work, but also to experiment with adjacent areas in order to learn how they work? Itâ€™s at this point that I think we gain more from the use of LLMsÂ today.

Beyond automating manual and exhausting tasks, the AI boost can be applied to our training, enabling dialogues and cooperation with peers that used to be very difficult. And, returning to our dear Edgar Morin, collective thinking becomes more complex because, even though each person maintains their specialization, everyone can understand or do the basics of their teammatesâ€™ workâ€Šâ€”â€Ševen if with lessÂ depth.

I think this is a very subtle difference, but fundamental for understanding the difference between production and innovation in the twenty-first century.

Want to talk more about this?
Send me a message on LinkedIn.

title: The new UX Toolkit: data, context, and evals
text:
The new UX Toolkit: data, context, and evals

Designing how modelsÂ behave.

We have entered a world where the experience is generated in the moment, and users react to it. The days when products rendered code that produced exactly what we designed are numbered. When someone uses an AI product, they are responding to behavior unfolding in real time, shaped by probabilistic systems rather than fixed screens. This marks a break from the era where designers could predict and control every outcome, and it forces UX to confront a new kind of material.

AI products are defined by non-deterministic behavior. The experience is something that unfolds on the fly, produced by AI models. What users see, read, hear, or are guided through is the result of systems making decisions on their behalf. Yet much of the current focus in UX and AI remains on production speed. Faster prototyping. Vibe coding. These practices matter, but they stop short of addressing the real shift AI introduces.

The real transformation of our craft lies in designing how the modelÂ behaves.

Engineering, and now Product, have moved upstream. They shape models, constrain outputs, define system behavior, and determine what is possible or impossible. UX often treats the model as a black box and designs around it. The result is AI products that may appear user-centered, but are often misaligned with the user intent and, at times,Â harmful.

How it worksÂ today

In many organizations, engineering and product teams are already designing the core of the experience. Not through screens, but through system prompts, fine-tuning strategies, tool definitions, orchestration logic, and evaluation frameworks. They are using an AI product Flywheel, and iterating constantly. UX is often brought in downstream to make the output feel nicer, more on-brand. That is not where the real leverageÂ is.

During a talk last summer, Andrew Ng argued that the real bottleneck is no longer engineering, but product. As AI accelerates code production, the hard part becomes deciding what to build. His advice was for PMs to talk to users, develop empathy, create mental models of the users they areÂ serving.

UX was notably absent from this framing, which says a lot about how poorly our discipline has articulated its value. The proposal is for product management to take on a larger role relative to engineering, even changing the ratio. His example shifts from one PM to four engineers, to one PM to half an engineer. As this space opens up for product, it should open to designers as well, with comparable influence. After all, understanding users, framing problems, and deciding why we build things have always been core toÂ UX.

A necessary mental shift for designers

For designers, this is a new space to conquer; it requires a mental shift away from deterministic systems and toward behavioral design. This does not mean abandoning user-centered design, it means applying it where it matters most. Models are not magic, they are material that can be designed.

â€œIn the pre-software age the only thing designers had to worry about was how a product was built. But in the post-software era we have to think about how the products will behave. Thatâ€™s a new paradigm and many people are still stuck in the pre-software era when it comes to designâ€¦â€â€Šâ€”â€ŠOvetta Sampson and Tim Brown (99UÂ 2019)

For us to enter this space, we need to get educated. Not to become AI engineers, but to understand how behavior emerges from systems. That means asking about training data, shaping the context a model processes, and contributing to evaluation strategies that define what is acceptable and what isÂ not.

Some companies are already ahead of the curve. They employ Model Designers whose work focuses explicitly on shaping model behavior. This is a reality at companies like OpenAI, Google and Figma, but it should not be treated as an exception. Every organization building AI products needs this capability within its design practice, whether as a dedicated role or as a core skill embedded in existing designÂ roles.

The new toolkit: Data, context, andÂ evals

When AI models are the material, then data, context, and evals are the tools we need to shape it. Letâ€™s get familiar with your newÂ tools.

Data shapes what a model knows and what it predicts. Pretraining data, fine-tuning data, and data generated during interaction shape what will be generated, and no data is created equally. Designers should be asking what kinds of behavior this data encourages, what perspectives it excludes, and also how it was acquired.

We are immersed in a world of large multimodal models, where much of the data has been scraped from the internet, often taken from authors without consent, and filled with biases and unfair patterns. As designers, we also must question whether this is the path we want to take, or whether smaller, more ethical models are the betterÂ choice.

Context shapes what a model can consider in the moment. This includes user input, environmental signals, retrieved knowledge, system prompts, safeguards, and instructions. The context window is where most of the experience is assembled. Writing system prompts, instructions, and constraints is design work. It is mostly done using plain, simple language with XLM markups, and of course AI can help designers with thisÂ process.

Lately, we have witnessed AI models generate adult content, sometimes involving minors, often without consent from the real people in the images. We have seen models suggest harmful acts during conversations, in some heartbreaking cases resulting in death. Choosing not to implement strong safeguards, or deciding not to block or redirect certain conversations, is also a design decision. With technology this powerful, designers must be truly intentional about defining what systems should notÂ do.

Evals determine what success means. What is acceptable. What is unsafe. What must never happen. Deciding what to measure is deciding what matters. It is highly influential, and for most AI companies evaluations have become the moat. Without evals, we cannot know what is failing or how broken a system reallyÂ is.

This becomes especially critical when working with large pre-trained models (such as GPT or Gemini). These models are continuously updated, and engineering teams will change them over time. How do you know whether a new version performs better for your product than the previous one. How can you recover quickly knowing that the user will be ok. This is where evaluations comeÂ in.

A good place to start is with frameworks. These are highly use-case dependent and often form part of a companyâ€™s secret sauce. One framework I find useful is RISK. Relevant, Inclusive, Safe, and Kind. We want to measure if and how often the output is relevant, whether it is a generated interface or a response.

Strong evaluation strategies also mix different types of evaluators:

1/Human evaluations involve manually reviewing outputs. They are necessary, but expensive andÂ slow.

2/Automated evaluators complement human judgment.

  • Code-based evaluators are deterministic tools that apply explicit, predefined logic.
  • LLM as Judge evaluators use language models to assess quality along dimensions that are difficult to encode in traditional code.

Once we have evaluations in place, we can start to measure results and decide how to act on them to improve the product. This might include adding new data sets for fine-tuning, grounding responses by connecting to a knowledge base, revising context through system prompt changes, or even introducing antagonistic models. We work with data, context, and evaluations in a continuous AI flywheel of improvement.

Agentic design and systemicÂ thinking

Agentic design is not about a single model responding to a user. It is about ecosystems of specialized AI agents, each with its own instructions, memory, tools, and goals. They coordinate, hand off tasks, make decisions, and act overÂ time.

Designing this requires systemic thinking. Designers must understand how agents work, how they delegate, how failures propagate, and how users control these workflows.

There are many definitions of agents today. But at their core, they are AI models and rely on the same design materials. Your new toolkit: Data, context,Â evals.

Final thoughts

We might not need AI atÂ all.

Before jumping into the hype, technology should not be the thing driving the solution. Many problems can and should be solved with simpler systems. When AI is truly needed, smaller or more specialized models are often better than massive multimodal ones for everyday goals. They are easier to shape, easier to evaluate, and less risky for users. If an organization chooses to build on large, popular multimodal models, then being a critical participant in shaping behavior becomes non-negotiable.

Engineering looks after the technology. Product looks after the business. The user, however, is alone withoutÂ us.

This is where UX must step in. Designers need to move upstream, working alongside engineering and product to shape AI products end-to-end.

Go and learn your newÂ tools.

Note: If this resonates and you want to build these skills with your team, I offer the Model Designer workshop. It is a hands-on training for designers shaping AI behavior through data, context, and evaluations. Available now.

title: Is separation of concerns a goal or a lie?
text:
Is separation of concerns a goal or a lie?

The one with React, Tailwind and the separation ofÂ concerns

When I started learning about web development I learned clean HTML, vanilla JavaScript and pure CSS, which are three different ways of saying: â€œNo Frameworksâ€.

Thatâ€™s the way most developers learned to code, at least in my age group, since we didnâ€™t have any framework other than jQuery back then, and AI coding assistants werenâ€™t a thingÂ yet.

Years later I did learn React (a JavaScript framework) and I did had to get to know Tailwind (a CSS framework) for work projects so everyone in the development team would be on the sameÂ page.

For years I didnâ€™t understand why React or Tailwind worked in the way they did, I felt frustrated because every little thing seemed to require more work then in plain JavaScript orÂ CSS.

I didnâ€™t think those frameworks save me much time or work in the long run and I was annoyed that I had to use them everyÂ day.

When I asked other developers about that, they often cited the concept of â€œseparation of concernsâ€ as a reason that makes React simpler to use or more suitable for team projects.

At the time I didnâ€™t get it. But nowâ€Šâ€”â€Šafter years of working with React and Tailwind I think Iâ€™m finally getting it. If youâ€™re anything like I was, confused or frustrated about it, please keepÂ reading.

What is separation ofÂ concerns

Separation of concerns is a programming term that means that any â€œproblemâ€ can be separated into smaller and easier to deal with â€œconcernsâ€.

In our example the â€œconcernsâ€ are just long code that is hard to grasp all at once. HTML has a few ways of dealing with code that is too complex already built-in to the technology.

One way we can handle code thatâ€™s too long is to separate it into different filesâ€Šâ€”â€ŠHTML for the content, CSS for the styles and JavaScript (js files) for functions.

This way you can more easily separate the different areas youâ€™re dealing with: HTML for the structure, CSS when you handle the design and JavaScript when you handle the hardcore programming stuff.

Of course in real projects every file will be in multiples, multiple HTML files for different pages (or parts of pages), multiple CSS files for different aspects of the design and multiple JavaScript files for different kinds of functions.

As the project goes up in complexity the pile of files gets bigger and it is murky at best where is the line to split theÂ files.

If weâ€™ll take for example CSS files, as it is closest to the design aspect and so easier to explain, we have multiple options how to sliceÂ it:

  1. Maybe just to work with one hugeÂ file
  2. Slicing it to smaller files by platform: Desktop.css, Mobile.css etc.
  3. Slicing it by components: Header.css, Footer.css, Button.css etc.
  4. Slicing it by pages: Index.css, About.css, Contact.cssÂ â€¦ General.css
  5. Slicing it by function: Common.css, Breakpoints.css, Vars.cssÂ etc.

It isnâ€™t clear at all where to draw the line of separation and Iâ€™ve seen many teams do it in very different ways, sometimes even combining more than one option unintentionally.

So how can React and Tailwind help us toÂ decide?

The component basedÂ approach

Let me preface what Iâ€™m about to say with that, like HTML, thereâ€™s lots of ways of making a ReactÂ app.

The most common way is to separate each component into its own file, so weâ€™ll end up with files named Button.jsx, Checkbox.jsx, Avatar.jsx, Card.jsxÂ etc.

These components get imported into different screens with different configurations (via props) so the code inside the components will potentially get replicated an infinite amount ofÂ times.

Unlike HTML, we donâ€™t need to manually copy the code to different places and different files, we just import the component and React will swap its code into every place weâ€™ve called itÂ from.

If weâ€™re thinking about the separation of concerns, what React does is very different from HTML, CSS and pure JavaScriptÂ .

HTML, CSS and JavaScript separate our concerns into multiple areas of responsibility, while React takes a different approach.

React separates our concerns based on component structure, so different developers can work on different components without bumping into oneÂ another.

But theyâ€™re all React developers, no longer a CSS specialist or an HTML architect, everyone is doing the same kind of work but on different buildingÂ blocks.

The distinction here is major since it slices the work for optimization rather than for specialization, which is almost the opposite approach.

Entering TailwindÂ CSS

Tailwind is a very popular CSS framework that works as a utility framework meaning all styles are done with inline classes instead of a big giant stylesheet.

This way you can copy and paste components from different layouts and ensure they will look exactly the same, of course when working with React components, the component gets imported into many layouts, pages or screens so consistency is keyâ€Šâ€”â€Šand Tailwind enables justÂ that.

If this is your first time seeing Tailwind code, I implore you to go and try it out, itâ€™s not as strange to work with as it might seem at first glance and it is much better than making inlineÂ styles.

Now that every codebase is in some degree written with AI I canâ€™t stress this enoughâ€Šâ€”â€ŠTailwind is much better than regular inline styles, if youâ€™re a CSS purist working with a stylesheet file or files thatâ€™s great, even a simple inline style here and there is mostlyÂ fine.

But never let the AI just make lots and lots of inline styles for everything, always ask to convert them to another file or just to work with Tailwind, inline styles are unmaintainable in the longÂ run.

I know what you must be thinking when encountering Tailwind, and itâ€™s the title of the nextÂ section.

What happened to separation of concerns?

I know that at first it looks like our separation of concerns is gone, React already implements all the HTML (via JSX) and the JavaScript in the sameÂ files.

Tailwind CSS takes it even further and it pulls the CSS utility classes into the JSX as well, instead of leaving them on separateÂ files.

That way we donâ€™t get any separation by areas anymore, the functions, design and structure all live together.

What we DO get, however, is separation by component, which can be more useful for big teams who work on the same system or same project together.

Separation by component means that even though a developer might be working on all the different areas of an Avatar component, the same developer doesnâ€™t need to be concerned about the Button component while doingÂ it.

Tailwind CSS ensures that all components will be designed as planned, even if they were designed in isolation, outside the system itself, since its utility classes are all deterministic by design and no style should ever leak outside its intendedÂ scope.

Conclusion

Separation of concerns is subjective and it is done differently in different systems, React and Tailwind do it component-based while pure HTML and CSS are more area-based.

There is no right answer to how you should do it, but consistency is key, especially when working in aÂ team.

Guidelines and best practices are great, but a separation that is inherit to the technology itself will always be better since everyone in the team can agree onÂ it.

When we consider a separation of concerns based on areas of expertise we can also consider to hire a CSS specialist, for example, but a Button specialist is not currently a job title, and maybe it should be as React and Tailwind becomes moreÂ popular.

I didnâ€™t touch on all the ways to separate CSS into multiple files and achieve something similar to component-based separation of concerns in pure HTML and CSS because I donâ€™t believe itâ€™s the right way to go when working in largeÂ teams.

There are a million technologies out there and a million ways to solve this issue, but I picked React and Tailwind as an example since itâ€™s a very popular solution.

This article only scratched theÂ surface.

I hope you enjoyed it, thanks forÂ reading.

title: The safest decision is rarely the right one
text:
The safest decision is rarely the right one

What we can learn from Linear about trusting judgement without ignoringÂ evidence

Data feels objective, defensible, and safe. In many product teams, it has quietly become the most powerful decision-maker in the roomâ€Šâ€”â€Šnot because it consistently leads to better outcomes, but because it removes personal accountability. When a decision can be justified with numbers, no one has to truly ownÂ it.

â€œAlthough you may think that people instinctively want to make the best possible decision, there is a stronger force that animates business decision-making: the desire not to get blamed orÂ fired.â€
â€” Rory Sutherland

â€˜Data-driven designâ€™ is often framed as maturity. In practice, it can become a way to defer judgement, smooth over disagreement, and default to the option that will attract the least resistance. The result isnâ€™t better productsâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s safer ones. Incremental improvements which optimise what already exists, while bolder ideas are quietly filtered out because they canâ€™t yet beÂ proven.

The uncomfortable truth is that data doesnâ€™t make decisions, people do. Data can inform, challenge, and validateâ€Šâ€”â€Šbut it canâ€™t decide what should exist, only describe what has happened before. When teams hide behind metrics, theyâ€™re not being rigorous; theyâ€™re avoiding the risk that comes with choosing a direction and standing behindÂ it.

â€œItâ€™s important to remember that big data all comes from the same placeâ€Šâ€”â€ŠtheÂ past.â€
â€” Rory Sutherland

How Linear balances judgement andÂ evidence

In an interview reflecting on Linearâ€™s design philosophy, co-founder and designer Karri Saarinen speaks directly about the limits of â€œhiding behind dataâ€ and the harder work of judgement. He describes how teams often lean on quantitative signals because theyâ€™re afraid of making the wrong choiceâ€Šâ€”â€Šand how data becomes a comforting shield. But that safety is an illusion. Data doesnâ€™t make choices for you; it only reports what has already happened.

Too much deference to metrics doesnâ€™t just slow teams downâ€Šâ€”â€Šit actively pushes them toward incrementalism. When evidence is treated as a prerequisite for action rather than an input into judgement, bold ideas struggle to survive long enough to beÂ tested.

Whatâ€™s striking in Saarinenâ€™s thinking is his insistence that product teams should feel empowered to decide based on a deep understanding of the problem, and rich context gained from direct engagement with users and the productâ€Šâ€”â€Šnot just dashboards or scoreboard metrics.

At Linear, design isnâ€™t something you outsource to analyticsâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s a product philosophy. They pursue quality not as a growth tactic or a differentiator, but because they believe good software should be well made. Craft isnâ€™t justified by metrics; itâ€™s a responsibility the team chooses to take seriously.

Rather than waiting for perfect metrics before acting, Linear routinely builds features and ships them to internal users or small opt-in groups earlyâ€Šâ€”â€Ševen when the experience is rough. This accelerates learning, sharpens judgement, and creates real feedback long before broad exposure. Engineers and designers are encouraged to own problems end-to-end, including small inefficiencies that may not yet register in analytics, but materially affect the lived experience ofÂ users.

Data is a tool, not aÂ crutch

Saarinen points out that teams often invoke data when theyâ€™re afraid to own a decision. At Linear, they donâ€™t rely on exhaustive ranking exercises or metric-driven roadmaps to determine direction. Instead, decisions emerge from a blendÂ of:

  • Direct customer conversations and qualitative feedback
  • Foundersâ€™ and team intuition, shaped by deep product familiarity
  • Contextual signals from realÂ usage

Data is still present, but it becomes one signal in a broader conversation, not the authority that endsÂ it.

â€œData isnâ€™t badâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s just not the decision-maker.â€
â€” KarriÂ Saarinen

Build with confidence, fail fast, and fixÂ things

Linear treats mistakes as an expected part of building good products. This flips the narrative from fear to responsibility. Designers and product leads arenâ€™t protected by metrics; theyâ€™re accountable for choicesâ€Šâ€”â€Šand expected to correct them quickly when theyâ€™reÂ wrong.

â€œSometimes we make the wrong choice, and then we just fix itâ€Šâ€”â€Šbut at least we made the choice, and the data didnâ€™t make the choice forÂ us.â€
â€” KarriÂ Saarinen

Safe decisions are rarely transformative

Safe decisions are rarely transformativeâ€Šâ€”â€Šand transformative decisions are rarely safe. Direction at Linear is chosen through judgement informed by deep engagement with users, even when the metrics havenâ€™t caught upÂ yet.

By combining context, craft, judgement, and fast feedback loops, teams can avoid both extremes: blind intuition on one side, and the paralysis of waiting for perfect data on theÂ other.

What we can learn fromÂ Linear

Ship early andÂ often

Donâ€™t wait for perfect analytics before releasing. Internal launches and small cohorts create faster, richer learning than prolonged analysis everÂ will.

Build shared product understanding

Distribute customer stories, recordings, and qualitative insights. When context is shared, judgement becomes defensible without needing a dashboard to prove everyÂ choice.

Treat data as input, not authority

Use metrics to inform and challenge intuition, not replace it. Data should contribute to decisionsâ€Šâ€”â€Šnot make them byÂ default.

Give designers space to pursueÂ craft

Quality isnâ€™t always measurable upfront, but itâ€™s immediately felt. When teams prioritise craft, they make better decisions because theyâ€™re deeply attuned to user experience.

Close the accountability loop

Make decisions based on expertise and judgementâ€Šâ€”â€Šthen measure the outcome. Celebrate learning, not just success. Thatâ€™s how intuition becomes a skill, not a superstition.
